comments:
This course covers advanced human embryology, physiology, and pathophysiology. The development of the human fetus and biochemical genetics and the study of genetics as a predisposition to disease are also discussed in this class. A course in anatomy and physiology is required to take this class.

Students generally found this class to be very learning-intensive and reported gaining much knowledge as a result of taking it. Most students found the class to be extremely challenging but also very rewarding.

Many students praised Professor Trimarchi’s lecturing ability, citing her aptitude for breaking down and presenting the material covered in class in a coherent, understandable fashion. Students attributed their ability to stay afloat in the course due to her help and assistance with the material.

This class is not targeted at undergraduate students, but is geared more for graduate and post-graduate students seeking to expand their knowledge in human development from a health standpoint. Many students reported this class as being “the hardest they have taken,” but also stated that they learned much about the topics covered. The tests given in class were characterized as “too large” in terms of their size and the material covered. Furthermore, some students complained about the sheer amount of the material that was covered in class (some 1800 pages) and the length of the class itself (5 hours, once a week).

This course covers advanced human embryology, physiology, and pathophysiology. The development of the human fetus and biochemical genetics and the study of genetics as a predisposition to disease are also discussed in this class. A course in anatomy and physiology is required to take this class.

Students generally found this class to be very learning-intensive and reported gaining much knowledge as a result of taking it. Most students found the class to be extremely challenging but also very rewarding.

Many students found Professor Marino’s lectures to be “very long” and sometimes off-topic. Several also believed that the material covered by Professor Marino’s lectures was not covered fairly on the course exams.
